The authors explained that the enhanced H2 production activity of interior Cu-doped ZnxCd1-xS was due to the introduction of a new donor level populated by partially filled Cu 3d orbitals above the VB of ZnxCd1-xS and a broadened light absorption range; the enhanced H2 production activity of surface Cu-doped ZnxCd1-xS was due to the generation of a new electrons transfer path (electrons directly transfer from the valence band of ZnxCd1-xS to surface CuS particles) and the rapid participation of photogenerated electrons in the H2 production through the active sites (CuS particles). Wang et al. [160]synthesized the surface P-doped g-C3N4 through the heat treatment of the mixture of NaH2PO2 and g-C3N4; P doping could cause the increased light absorption, upshifted CB position with improved reduction potential and effective separation of photogenerated carriers in g-C3N4. Therefore, the P-doped g-C3N4 exhibited the significantly improved photocatalytic H2 production activity of 916.2 μmol/g/h (quantum efficiency of 6.52% at 420 nm), which was about two times higher than that of the pristine g-C3N4 [160]. Construction of reasonable surface defects has been widely studied in photocatalytic water splitting, which can be an effective method for the enhanced photocatalytic H2 production. For example, Tan et al. [161]treated the mixed SrTiO3 and NaBH4 at different temperatures in the Ar atmosphere to obtain a series of SrTiO3 with different levels of surface oxygen vacancies; the produced surface oxygen vacancies could significantly enhance the photocatalytic H2 production activity of the original SrTiO3 (as shown in Fig. 16 ). The authors thought that the oxygen vacancies expanded the light absorption range and promoted the separation of photogenerated carriers, which were the reasons for the improvement of photocatalytic H2 production activity [161]. Zuo et al. [162] calcined a mixture of ethanol, hydrochloric acid, titanium isopropoxide, and 2-methylimidazole in air at 500 °C for 5 h to obtain the blue TiO2-x with abundant oxygen vacancies, and the introduction of oxygen vacancies could shorten the energy bandgap and expand the light absorption range which was beneficial to the improvement of visible-light photocatalytic H2 production. In addition to oxygen vacancies, the surface sulfur vacancies could also play an important role for the improvement of photocatalytic H2 production. For example, Zhang et al. [163]synthesized Zn-Cd-S solid solution with surface sulfur vacancies in hydrazine hydrate, and surface sulfur vacancies in Zn-Cd-S solid solution could shorten the band gap and expand the light absorption range, which caused a four-fold enhanced photocatalytic H2 production activity than that of Zn-Cd-S solid solution without sulfur vacancies. In a similar report, Wang et al. [164] synthesized the ZnS with controllable sulfur vacancies, which could expand its light absorption range from ultraviolet light to visible light and greatly enhance the visible-light photocatalytic H2 production performance than that of pure ZnS without sulfur vacancies. Huang et al. [122]reported that the twining Cd0.6Zn0.4S solid solution with rich sulfur vacancies showed a remarkable visible-light photocatalytic H2 production activity (42.66 mmol/g/h) with Na2S/Na2SO3 solution as a sacrificial agent; the surface sulfur vacancies were a benefit to the absorption of sacrificial agent (S2−) and the consumption of photogenerated holes, which improved the separation efficiency of photogenerated carriers [122]. Therefore, it can be seen that the design of doping and surface defects plays a very important role in improving the photocatalytic H2 production from water splitting.

4.3 Heterojunction construction Heterojunction construction is the most important method in interfacial regulation engineering for electrocatalytic and photocatalytic water splitting, which can optimize the interface structure, improve the adsorption and desorption abilities of intermediates on the catalyst surface during electrocatalytic water splitting, and accelerate the rapid transfer and effective separation of photogenerated carriers during photocatalytic water splitting. 4.3.1 Heterojunction construction in electrocatalytic water splitting Heterojunction construction is widely used in electrocatalytic water splitting, and it can optimize the interfacial property and make full use of the advantages of the two kinds of electrocatalysts. For examples, Yang et al. [165]synthesized a self-supported MoS2-Ni3S2 heterojunction on Ni foam, and Ni3S2 nanorods and ultrathin MoS2 nanosheets constituted a three dimensional hierarchical heterostructure that exhibited a superior electrocatalytic water splitting activity in 1.0 M KOH (the overpotential required for HER to reach 10 mA/cm2 is 98 mV, Tafel slope is 61 mV/dec; and the overpotential required for OER to reach 10 mA/cm2 is 249 mV, Tafel slope is 57 mV/dec). The excellent activity of MoS2-Ni3S2 heterojunction is attributed to the favorable interface which is beneficial for the absorption and desorption of H and O intermediates, more exposed active sites, and the favorable charge transport along 1D Ni3S2 nanorods immobilized on Ni foam [165]. Chen et al. [166]successfully synthesized the 1T-VS2@MoS2 heterojunction by a two-step method; the metal phase VS2 promoted the efficient charge transfer, and MoS2 with more exposed edge sites can act as the active sites for the electrocatalytic HER. The synergistic effect in the 1T-VS2@MoS2 heterojunction realized a superior electrocatalytic HER activity with a low overpotential of 177 mV at 10 mA/cm2 and a small Tafel slope of 54.9 mV/dec. Similar report shows that the MoS2 nanosheet–modified CoS2 nanowire heterojunction exhibited an excellent electrocatalytic HER activity than MoS2 or CoS2 alone [167]. In addition to these, some other reports on heterojunctions include the optimization of the absorption and desorption process of H2O, H, or O intermediate through interface engineering, which can promote the kinetics of the catalytic reaction. For examples, Zhang et al. [168] reported the synthesis of Ni(OH)2/MoS2 heterojunctions with rich active interfaces which could achieve a better alkaline HER activity (ηoneset is 20 mV, η10 is 80 mV and Tafel slope is 60 mV/dec) than that of MoS2 alone, as shown in Fig. 17. Furthermore, the DFT calculation was used in the key reaction steps of electrocatalytic HER to study the synergistic effect of Ni(OH)2/MoS2 heterojunction, as shown in Fig. 18; the Ni(OH)2/MoS2 heterojunction exhibited less water-activated adsorption free energy (ΔGH2O) and hydrogen adsorption free energy (ΔGH) in both the Ni(OH)2/MoS2 interface and the MoS2 side or Ni(OH)2 side in Ni(OH)2/MoS2 heterojunction. Therefore, the construction of the Ni(OH)2/MoS2 heterojunction can effectively reduce the kinetic barrier of the initial water splitting step and hydrogen intermediate desorption and aggregation [168]. Similar reports include the Ni(OH)2–Ni3N nanosheet heterojunction [169], Co(OH)2@MoS2 heterojunction [170], and so on, which showed the similar mechanism for the enhanced HER activity. 4.3.2 Heterojunction construction in photocatalytic water splitting During the photocatalytic water splitting for H2 production, construction of suitable heterojunction is a widely studied topic, which can effectively promote the separation of photogenerated carriers and improve the photocatalytic H2 production activity [171]. Usually, the formation of type II heterojunction with staggered band structure is beneficial to the photogenerated carrier separation. As shown in Fig. 19 , photocatalyst I (PS I) and photocatalyst II (PS II) are excited by light with enough energy (hv > Eg), the photogenerated electrons in the CB of PS I can transfer to the CB of PS II, and the photogenerated holes in the VB of PS II can transfer to the VB of PS I because of the staggered band structure, which can effectively improve the separation efficiency of photogenerated carriers. Meanwhile, the interface of heterojunction plays an important role in photocatalysis, because it is the only way for photogenerated carrier transfer. Close contact and good matching interfaces is good for facilitating the separation and transfer of photogenerated carriers. For examples, Hu et al. [172]deposited InVO4 nanoparticles (20 nm) on g-C3N4 nanosheets to form a close-contact g-C3N4/InVO4 type II heterojunction by the hydrothermal method; because of the staggered energy band positions of g-C3N4 and nano-InVO4, the formed interface electric field and closely contacted heterogeneous interface effectively promoted the separation and transfer of photogenerated electron–hole pairs, which greatly improved the photocatalytic H2 production activity of g-C3N4 or InVO4 alone [172]. Zhang et al. [173] synthesized a core–shell CdS/g-C3N4 heterojunction by the spontaneous adsorption of g-C3N4 on the CdS nanowire (Fig. 20 a–c), which can achieve the efficient separation of photogenerated carriers under visible light because of the formation of close-contact type II heterojunction, as shown in Fig. 20d [173]. Therefore, the photocatalytic H2 production activity got improved in the CdS/g-C3N4 heterojunction system (Fig. 20e), which is higher than that of g-C3N4 alone; more importantly, the photocorrosion of CdS can be effectively inhibited by the transfer of photogenerated holes from the VB of CdS to the VB of g-C3N4, and the stability of CdS/g-C3N4 heterojunction was improved. Other similar reports include the AgIn5S8/TiO2 heterojunction [174], TiO2/g-C3N4 heterojunction [175], ZnS/g-C3N4 heterojunction [176], and so on, which all exhibited the enhanced photocatalytic H2 production activities. The p–n junction is also one kind of semiconductor heterojunctions, as shown in Fig. 21 a. When the p-type and n-type semiconductors contact with each other, carrier diffusion occurs at the contacted interface because of the different Fermi levels, the electrons in the n-type semiconductor will diffuse into the p-type semiconductor, and the holes in the p-type semiconductor will diffuse into the n-type semiconductor; the diffusion of the electrons and holes will continue till the Fermi level of the system reaches equilibrium. Because of the diffusion, a space charge region is formed at the interface, called the built-in electric field, and the direction of the electric field is directed to the p-type semiconductor [177]. When the p–n junction is irradiated by light with enough energy, the semiconductors are excited and produce the photogenerated electrons and holes; under the driving of the built-in electric field, the photogenerated electrons in the CB of the p-type semiconductor will rapidly migrate to the CB of the n-type semiconductor, and the photogenerated holes in the VB of n-type semiconductor will rapidly migrate to the VB of p-type semiconductor, which can effectively promote the spatial separation of the photogenerated carriers and improve the photocatalytic activity. For examples, Chen et al. [178]successfully grew p-type Cu2S on n-type CdS by in situ deposition and constructed many nanoscale p–n junctions (Fig. 21b), the photogenerated carriers were effectively separated because of the built-in electric field (Fig. 21c); therefore, the photocatalytic H2 production activity of CdS was greatly enhanced (Fig. 21d). In addition, the authors loaded p-type Cu2S on the other n-type semiconductors (ZnIn2S4 and TiO2) to construct p–n junctions, and the photocatalytic H2 production activity could still get promoted, demonstrating the universality of the p–n junction to improve the photocatalytic H2 activity [178]. There are other similar reports about the application of p–n junctions in the improvement of photocatalytic H2 production, such as Co3O4/CdS [179], Cu3P/CdS [180], Cu2O/TiO2 [181], and so on. Although the aforementioned heterojunction systems can improve the separation efficiency of photogenerated carriers, they all reduce the redox abilities of the photocatalysts, which is not good for the photocatalysis. Developing the efficient heterojunction systems with the efficient separation efficiency and maintained redox abilities of photogenerated carriers is really very important for photocatalytic water splitting. In recent years, Z-type heterojunction systems have been extensively studied, as shown in Fig. 22 a. Under light irradiation with enough energy, the photogenerated electrons in the CB of photocatalyst PS II can migrate and recombine with the photogenerated holes in the VB of photocatalyst PS I either directly or by bridging (electron transport medium or redox couple); thus the photogenerated electrons on the CB of PS I and the photogenerated holes on the VB of PS II can be effectively separated and maintain the corresponding redox ability to take part in the photocatalytic water splitting [177]. For examples, Zhang et al. [182]reported the application of the CdS/WO3 Z-type heterojunction in photocatalytic H2 production; the CdS/WO3 heterojunction exhibited five times higher H2 production activity than that of CdS alone under the same conditions due to the efficient charge transfer and separation. Xu et al. [183]successfully fabricated the 2D/2D Fe2O3/g-C3N4 direct Z-scheme photocatalyst via an electrostatic self-assembly method, and the Z-scheme charge transfer route can realize the spatial isolation of charge carriers and maintain the strong redox ability of photogenerated electron–hole pairs in Fe2O3/g-C3N4 system (Fig. 22b), which achieved about 13-fold photocatalytic H2 production activity than that of g-C3N4 alone and the good stability (Fig. 22c and d) [183]. Wang et al. [184] synthesized the ZnO/CdS hierarchical composite by a hydrothermal and chemical bath deposition process and further verified the direct Z-scheme charge transfer mechanism by the in situ XPS measurements and detection of the production of hydroxyl radicals, which exhibited significantly enhanced photocatalytic H2 production performance. Other reports about Z-scheme heterojunctions include WO3/g-C3N4 [185], CoTiO3/g-C3N4 [186], CdS/cobalt-benzimidazole coordination polymers [187], etc.; they all show the enhanced photocatalytic H2 production activity. The maintained strong redox ability of Z-scheme heterojunction makes it to be the most promising system for pure water splitting.

sections: Cocatalyst modification in photocatalytic water splitting
Text: 4.4 Cocatalyst modification in photocatalytic water splitting The cocatalyst plays an important role in photocatalytic water splitting for H2 production; a suitable cocatalyst-modified photocatalyst can realize the significantly enhanced and efficient photocatalytic H2 production. The main functions of the cocatalyst in photocatalytic water splitting are (1) providing the active sites for the redox reaction and reducing the kinetic energy barrier or activation energy of the reaction and (2) rapid transfer of photogenerated carriers to participate the photocatalytic reaction. Among them, the rapid transfer of photogenerated holes can effectively inhibit the photocorrosion of some photocatalysts such as metal sulfide and nitride semiconductors. Photocatalytic water splitting contains two important half reactions, which are H2 production and O2 production; therefore, the cocatalysts for photocatalytic H2 and O2 production have been extensively studied to improve the performance. Precious metals Pt and Pd are excellent cocatalysts in photocatalytic H2 production, but they are greatly limited because of their high cost and limited reserves. In recent years, many inexpensive and abundant cocatalysts for photocatalytic H2 production have been developed. For examples, Yu and Ran [188] synthesized the Cu(OH)2 nanoparticle–modified P25 (TiO2) photocatalysts, where Cu(OH)2 nanoparticles are the cocatalyst; the loading of Cu(OH)2 as the cocatalyst can greatly improve the photocatalytic H2 production of P25 because of the effective charge transfer, and the optimal photocatalytic H2 production activity was got when the loading amount reached to 0.29 mol%, which was 205 times higher than that of P25 without a cocatalyst [188]. There are other similar reports on the use of hydroxides as cocatalysts to enhance the photocatalytic H2 production performances, such as Ni(OH)2-modified CdS and g-C3N4, where Ni(OH)2 is the cocatalyst, and Co(OH)2-modified CdS, where Co(OH)2 is the cocatalyst [189–191]. Non-precious metal–based Ni as a cocatalyst has been reported for improving the photocatalytic H2 production activity; for example, Kong et al. [192] utilized the rapid light-assisted reduction method to obtain the Ni(0)-modified g-C3N4 composites. The Ni/g-C3N4 showed the superior photocatalytic H2 production activity because of the efficient electrons transfer and abundant active sites supplied by Ni(0) [192]. Some transition metal sulfides have also been reported as the cocatalysts for efficient photocatalytic H2 production; for example, Liu et al. [123] synthesized the noble metal–free NiS–modified MnxCd1-xS solid solution, where the noble metal–free NiS is the cocatalyst. Fig. 23 b showed the mechanism that photogenerated electrons could quickly transfer to the cocatalyst (NiS) active sites and participate in the photocatalytic H2 production reaction under light irradiation; the optimal sample exhibited 18.6 times higher H2 production activity than that of Mn0.5Cd0.5S without the cocatalyst and even better than that of the Pt-loaded Mn0.5Cd0.5S (Fig. 23a) [123]. There are other reports about transition metal sulfides as cocatalysts for the improvement of photocatalytic H2 production activity, such as WS2-modified CdS [193], NiS-modified CdS [194], NiS-modified g-C3N4 [195], CoSx-modified g-C3N4 [196], and CuxS-modified Mn0.5Cd0.5S [197], where WS2, NiS, CoSx, and CuxS are cocatalysts, respectively. Because of the superior electrocatalytic HER performances of transition metal phosphides and nitrides, many of them were introduced into photocatalytic H2 production systems as cocatalysts, which exhibited superior performances for improving the photocatalytic H2 production. For example, Ye et al. [198] reported the synthesis of Ni2P-modified g-C3N4, where Ni2P is the cocatalyst. Ni2P/g-C3N4 exhibited a superior photocatalytic H2 production activity (82.5 μmol/h/g), which was even higher than that of Pt-loaded g-C3N4 (72 μmol/h/g); the photo-excited electrons can rapidly transfer from g-C3N4 to Ni2P, which can realize the efficient separation of photo-excited carriers, and Ni2P as the active sites can be beneficial to the photocatalytic H2 production [198]. Similar cocatalysts are also widely used in photocatalytic H2 production, such as CoP/CdxZn1-xSe, Cu3P/g-C3N4, Ni3N/g-C3N4, CoxP/CdS, and NixP/g-C3N4 composites [199–203]. Reduced graphene oxide is regarded as a good electronic conductor because of its good electrical conductibility, and it has been widely used as a cocatalyst to transfer photogenerated electrons in photocatalytic H2 production activity [204–206]. Currently emerging two-dimensional materials such as ultrathin black phosphorus (BP) and Ti3C2Tx as cocatalysts also showed excellent activity in photocatalytic H2 production. For example, Ran et al. [207] synthesized the BP-modified ZnS, Zn0.8Cd0.2S, and CdS composites, which showed a high photocatalytic activity and apparent quantum yield for H2 production because of the high charge mobility, massive active sites, and favorable band structure of BP [207]. Ran et al. [208] reported the Ti3C2 MXene nanoparticle as a cocatalyst integrated with CdS achieved a super high visible-light photocatalytic H2 production activity of 14.342 mmol/h/g and an apparent quantum efficiency of 40.1% at 420 nm, which was attributed to the favorable Fermi level position (forming Schottky junction), electrical conductivity, and abundant H2 production active sites of Ti3C2 nanoparticles [208]. These cocatalysts are all good H2 production active sites, which are beneficial to the photocatalytic H2 production at the surface of photocatalysts, and the rapid reaction of photogenerated electrons can reduce the recombination of photogenerated carriers. In addition to designing the reduction cocatalysts for the efficient photogenerated electrons transfer, developing the oxidation cocatalysts for effective photogenerated holes transfer also can improve the photocatalytic H2 production activity. For examples, Di et al. [209] reported the synthesis of the cobalt-phosphate (Co-Pi)–modified CdS nanorod and its application in photocatalytic H2 production. As shown in Fig. 24 a, the photogenerated holes were effectively captured by the Co-Pi cocatalyst and then rapidly consumed by the sacrificial agent of lactic acid, which avoided the recombination of photogenerated electrons and holes. The photocatalytic H2 production result (Fig. 24b) showed that Co-Pi cocatalyst modification significantly increased the activity of CdS, and the optimal Co-Pi/CdS exhibited the H2 production activity of 13.3 mmol/h/g with an apparent quantum efficiency of 24.3% at 420 nm, which was even better than that of 1.0 wt% Pt/CdS (11.3 mmol/h/g). Ai et al. [210] synthesized the MnOx-decorated 3D porous C3N4 via a simple salt template–assisted method, and they found that loading of MnOx as hole-trapping sites could effectively promote separation of charge carriers, which further improved the photocatalytic H2 production activity of 3D porous C3N4 for about 3.5 times. Yuan et al. [179] synthesized the amorphous Co3O4-modified CdS nanorods by a one-step solvothermal reaction; the photogenerated holes in CdS could transfer to the Co3O4 cocatalyst and then get consumed by the sacrificial agent of Na2S and Na2SO3 solution under visible light because of the formation of the p–n junction, which could promote the separation of photogenerated carriers and improve the photocatalytic H2 production activity of CdS for about 33 times [179]. In addition to the improved H2 production activity, the loading of oxidation cocatalysts for effective transfer the photogenerated holes to participate in photocatalytic reaction can also avoid the self-oxidation of sulfide photocatalysts; thereby their stability can be improved. Recently, it has been found that the loading of spatially separated dual cocatalysts (both reduction and oxidation cocatalysts) on photocatalysts can further enhance the photocatalytic H2 production activity, and because of the synergistic effect of dual cocatalysts, it can show better photocatalytic activity than the loading of single cocatalyst [211]. For examples, Zhang et al. [212] synthesized the spatially separated Pt and CoOx cocatalysts on the internal and external of porous TiO2 nanotubes by atomic layer deposition; with Pt as the reductive active sites and CoOx as the oxidative active sites, the photogenerated carriers got efficient separation under the synergistic effect of dual cocatalysts, and the photocatalytic H2 production activity of the sample was far higher than that of CoOx or Pt-loaded TiO2 [212]. In a similar report, Meng et al. [213] utilized the crystal face heterojunction of TiO2 to realize the loading of spatially separated dual cocatalysts (Co3O4 as the oxidative active sites and Pt as the reductive active sites) to achieve the efficient photocatalytic H2 production. Liu et al. [214] used an ingenious method to synthesize the spatially separated dual cocatalysts (Cu2-xS and MoS2)–modified Mn0.5Cd0.5S photocatalysts, as shown in Fig. 25 ; the p–n heterojunction between Cu2-xS and Mn0.5Cd0.5S could accelerate the photogenerated holes transfer to the Cu2-xS and the photogenerated electrons could transfer to the MoS2 which is the active sites for H2 production. Because of the synergistic effect of dual cocatalysts, the photogenerated carriers can realize efficient separation, and the photocatalytic H2 production activity of Mn0.5Cd0.5S can get remarkable improvement than those of Cu2-xS alone– or MoS2 alone–modified Mn0.5Cd0.5S [214].

sections: The relationship between the electrocatalytic and photocatalytic water splitting
Text: Electrocatalytic and photocatalytic water splitting are two very promising hydrogen production methods, which can utilize and convert the nature energy (wind and water energy for electrocatalytic water splitting and solar energy for photocatalytic water splitting) to the clean, renewable, and high–energy density H2 energy. They all utilize electrons and holes to take part in the water splitting for the H2 and O2 production on the surface of the catalyst; the most different is the source of electrons and holes. The electrons and holes in electrocatalytic water splitting come from the supplied electrical energy, and the electrons and holes in photocatalytic water splitting are derived from the excited semiconductor by the solar light. Water splitting reaction derived by the electrons and holes takes place on the surface or the interface of the catalyst. therefore, the surface and interfacial properties of the catalyst play important roles for both electrocatalytic and photocatalytic water splitting activity. Some surface and interfacial regulation strategies, such as morphology regulation, construction of heterojunction, cocatalyst modification, doping, and construction of surface defects, play active roles in improving the electrocatalytic and photocatalytic water splitting performances. The most important point is that the development of advanced electrocatalysts is beneficial to the improvement of photocatalytic water splitting performance because the property and feature of advanced electrocatalyst are similar with the cocatalyst in photocatalysis, which plays an important role during the photocatalytic water splitting. Some advanced electrocatalysts can be used as superior cocatalysts in photocatalysis, which can provide more active sites, reduce the reaction energy barrier, and demonstrate good performance in promoting photocatalytic water splitting. Transition metal phosphides, the star materials in HER because of the superior electrical conductivity and Gibbs free energy for hydrogen adsorption, have been widely used as cocatalysts in photocatalytic water splitting. For example, Shi et al. [215]reported that the CoP as the cocatalyst can dramatically improve the performance of photocatalytic pure water splitting of P-doped CdS, which can effectively promote the transfer of photogenerated electrons for H2 production. There are some similar reports such as Ni2P- and MoP-modified CdS [216,217]. Transition metal nitrides, another commonly used HER electrocatalysts, which have superior electrical conductivity and corrosion resistance, also can be used as cocatalysts in photocatalytic H2 production. For example, Chen et al. [201] reported the photocatalytic H2 production performance of the noble metal–free Ni3N-modified g-C3N4, with Ni3N as the cocatalyst, is even slightly higher than that of 3 wt% Pt-modified g-C3N4. NiFe-LDH is recognized as a superior OER material, which can also be used as the efficient cocatalyst in photocatalytic water oxidation. For example, Bai et al. [218]synthesized the NiFe-LDH nanosheets–modified Fe2O3/BiVO4 heterojunction, which could effectively hinder the recombination of photogenerated electron–hole pairs and improve the performance of photocatalytic water oxidation. Therefore, the development of advanced electrocatalysts has an important meaning for the photocatalytic water splitting.

Hydrogen as a clean, pollution-free, and renewable energy can effectively solve the energy shortage and environmental pollution problems around the world. Photocatalytic and electrocatalytic water splitting for H2 production have been widely studied because of their many advantages, such as being pollution-free, easy product separation, and so on. In this review article, we first introduce the mechanism and performance evaluation parameters of electrocatalytic and photocatalytic water splitting in detail; we point out that the main problems for electrocatalytic H2 production from water splitting are the overpotential and slow kinetics which can cause the waste of energy, and the main problem for photocatalytic H2 production from water splitting is the low conversion efficiency from solar energy to hydrogen energy. Then, we introduce the research process in electrocatalysts and photocatalysts, which are used for H2 production from water splitting. It is well known that almost all catalytic reactions are carried out on the surfaces and interfaces of the catalysts; therefore, the surface and interfacial conditions of the catalysts (component, structure, morphology, defect, active site, etc) will strongly affect their catalytic activities. Therefore, we summary the surface and interfacial regulation methods of the electrocatalysts and photocatalysts in detail, which contain morphology regulation, doping and construction of surface defects, construction of heterojunction, and cocatalyst modification. The implementation of these strategies can enhance the electrical conductivity, provide the favorable carrier transport path, obtain more active sites, change the surface and interfacial property for the favorable adsorption and desorption of reaction intermediates for electrocatalytic water splitting, expand the light absorption, support more active sites, and promote the efficient separation of photogenerated carriers for photocatalytic water splitting. These strategies are of great significance for realizing the efficient H2 production from water splitting. We hope that more efficient photocatalysts and electrocatalysts for water splitting can be explored, and more surface and interfacial regulation methods can be developed and applied to further improve the water splitting activity. During the photocatalytic water splitting, the cocatalysts for both H2 and O2 production are very similar to the electrocatalysts for HER and OER, respectively. Some metal sulfide, nitride and phosphide electrocatalysts have been widely used as cocatalysts in photocatalytic water splitting systems. Therefore, the development of electrocatalysts is very important for their application in photocatalytic water splitting fields. Exploring more efficient catalysts and developing more surface- and interface-modified strategies can improve the electrocatalytic and photocatalytic water splitting activities, which can effectively reduce the energy loss during electrocatalytic water splitting and improve the conversion efficiency from solar energy to H2 energy. We hope that the photocatalytic and electrocatalytic water splitting can achieve large-scale practical application for H2 production and, ultimately, solve the energy crisis and environmental pollution problems.
